author: Mike Kelly
title: Why minimum wage could go because of exodus of demonised low paid eastern Europeans
text:
News Opinion Why minimum wage could go because of exodus of demonised low paid eastern Europeans The gap will have to be plugged by low paid local staff which will mean workers rights going down the pan, says Mike Kelly Share Boris Johnson with the Vote Leave campaign bus (Photo: Stefan Rousseau/PA Wire) Share Get daily   
Brexit Secretary David Davis went on a two day trip to ‘woo’ the Baltic nations of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania last week. 
During it he reportedly promised them that the UK will not shut the door on low-skilled migrants post Brexit. 
He said: “In the hospitality sector, hotels and restaurants, in the social-care sector, working in agriculture, it will take time - it will be years and years before we get British citizens to do those jobs.” 
Many things sprung to mind on reading this. 
Wasn’t the central plank of the Brexit argument to leave Europe so that we English could pull up the drawbridge of our castles and fill the moats with sharks to keep out the low skilled eastern European ‘hordes’ who were taking all the jobs and houses from the locals? 
Or has that gone down the pan like the pledge to put £350m a week from saved European funds into the NHS? Brexit Secretary David Davis 
That was an idea that grabbed the public’s attention which may well have tipped the scales in favour of Brexit. 
Yet when it came down to it, Brexists like Boris Johnson voted against an amendment to the Brexit bill to include the £350m a week promise in extra funds to the NHS they championed. It’s almost as if they didn’t mean it. 
I was particularly struck by the Davis line that ‘it will be years and years before we get British citizens to do those jobs’. 
I suspect unemployed people would do them tomorrow - but not at the rate many eastern Europeans have been paid. 
For Brits to do the jobs by law they should be paid £7.20 an hour and there’s an awful lot of people in those sectors mentioned not getting anywhere near that amount. 
The ‘years and years’ could be the time it will take to get out of the EU after which the government can lay waste to the rights of UK workers that are enshrined in European law. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
